content.description: A dramatically sharp arete.  The crux is the first 20 feet of climbing after which the difficulty  eases to 5.9.  There are bolts on top for an anchor.
content.protection: Two old, rusty, button-head bolts and a third good bolt, which I added for safety.
content.location: A sharp arete about 20min walk up the Fuller Ridge trail.  Start right off the trail from the top of a boulder.  Pull on to the right side of the arete.  An interesting crux leads to fun climbing.  Someone climbed this a long time ago as the old bolts on top suggest.  My guess is it is a Scott Erler FA from the late 80's. Anyone know?  Also there are other quality routs at this crag. Anyone know the name of this climb/craig?

climbs.name: Standing in the Bed of a Wagon

content.description: A fun crank on beautiful rock. Start in a scoop and climb crimps and slopers straight up onto the shoulder of the boulder.
content.location: This is in a group of large boulders about 4 miles up the trail, on the west side of the trail, just past a prominent drainage.

content.description:
Sit start on the right and crank up into the powerful sloper traverse. Then go straight up with long moves between black chickenheads.

When I first visited this spot in 2014 it was pristine. It was sad and strange to return and find someone's crap strewn everywhere. Thus the name, Parallel Universe. Climbers share an interest in rocks but little else it seems.
content.location: Just right of Standing in the Bed of a Wagon.  The problem faces northeast.  Beomilf is on the opposite side of the same boulder.

content.description: Sustained stemming, jamming and lay backing.  A north facing open book.  It is possible that this route has been climbed before, but who and when?  As the name implies it has a thick coat of lichen growing in places, but the climbing is fun regardless.
content.protection: An anchor can be set with small TCU's.
content.location: 20 min hike up Fuller Ridge Trail.  Just above the obvious sharp arete on the side of the trail.

content.description: A great climb following the line of least resistance up the southwest side of the boulder.  Start on vertical orange and black patina and follow a discontinuous rail up and right.  A committing high step gains a small shelf on the upper slab, where spooky moves lead to the summit.
content.location: This is in a group of large boulders about 4 miles up the trail, on the west side of the trail, just past a prominent drainage.
